properties.Title: Civil Emergency, Update From Sk Provincial Emergency Communications Centre
properties.Summary:
Description: This emergency advisory alert is being issued for the province of Saskatchewan. All travelers returning from outside of Canada are subject to a mandatory 14 day self isolation order. Violation of the order may result in a fine of 2000 dollars.
Expires: 2021-03-31T17:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: SK Provincial Emergency Communications Centre, 2021-03-17T16:30:35-06:00, A32385F2-98FB-8B10-4148-DC3489465349
Area: Province of Saskatchewan
properties.Author: SK Provincial Emergency Communications Centre

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, followed by significant snowfall is expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 30 cm, with locally higher amounts possible in some areas. Locations: central and northeastern Newfoundland. Time span: Friday into Friday night. Remarks: Rain, mixed at first with snow, will begin towards midnight tonight. The rain will transition to snow, at times heavy, from west to east across central and northeastern Newfoundland as temperatures fall during the day on Friday. The snow will taper to flurries Friday night. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-19T10:25:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-18T18:26:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1637151312.2021
Area: Buchans and the interior, Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Gander and vicinity, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory Alert Is Being Extended By The Town Of Cabri.
properties.Summary:
Description: The Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory is being extended for the Town of Cabri. This advisory is for the entire community and for any individuals who may access water the Town of Cabri. water system. This advisory is in effect until further notice.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected on Friday. Accumulation: 15 to 20 cm. Location: Cape Breton and eastern mainland Nova Scotia. Remarks: Rain will change to snow, at times heavy, early Friday morning and will taper off by Friday afternoon. The highest accumulations will be along the Atlantic coast and over higher terrain. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall possible on Friday. Total snowfall: generally 5 to 15 cm, more possible over eastern Nova Scotia. Location: most of Nova Scotia. Remarks: Rain will change to snow early Friday morning then taper off Friday afternoon. The highest accumulations will be over eastern Nova Scotia, where snowfall warnings have been issued. Rapidly accumulating snowfall may impact the Friday morning commute in urban areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

Time span: tonight through Friday. Remarks: Precipitation is forecast to begin early this evening as mostly rain along the coast and snow inland, before transitioning to snow over all areas overnight into Friday morning. properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR QUESNEL March 18, 2021 08:00 - Kamloops) The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with the Northern Health Authority has issued a Dust Advisory for Quesnel because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation, dust suppression or a change in traffic patterns. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Exposure is particularly a concern for individuals with chronic conditions such as asthma, COPD, heart disease, and diabetes, respiratory infections such as COVID-19, pregnant women, infants, and older adults. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions or acute infections should postpone or reduce strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Where appropriate, maintain physical distancing. Anyone experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, should follow the advice of their health care provider. Staying indoors helps to reduce particulate matter exposure. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-03-19T07:28:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2021-03-18T15:29:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1553277484.2021
Area: Cariboo - north including Quesnel
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-19T05:21:02-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Locations: eastern and southeastern Newfoundland. Total rainfall: 20 to 40 mm, except 40 to 60 mm over the southern Avalon Peninsula and Burin Peninsula. Time span: tonight through Friday evening. Remarks: Rain will spread from west to east tonight, and then continue through Friday, before transitioning to snow late Friday into Friday night. The rain will be heavy at times, and accompanied by mild temperatures resulting in significant snowmelt and runoff. Local flooding is possible, especially in areas with poor drainage. As temperatures fall on Friday night, areas of standing water will quickly freezing resulting in icy and slippery surfaces. ### Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-19T10:27:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-18T18:28:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3983808668.2021
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Burin Peninsula, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. ROAD DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR GOLDEN (March 18, 2021 10:00 - Cranbrook) The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Interior Health has issued a Road Dust Advisory for Golden on March 17, 2021. The advisory remains in effect due to high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation, dust suppression or a change in traffic patterns. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Exposure is a concern for pregnant women, infants, and older adults, as well as, individuals with conditions such as asthma, COPD, heart disease, diabetes or respiratory infections such as COVID-19. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions or acute infections should postpone or reduce strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Where appropriate, maintain physical distancing. Anyone experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, should follow the advice of their health care provider. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-03-19T12:35:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2021-03-18T20:36:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3853521684.2021
Area: East Columbia

properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, followed by significant snowfall is expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 30 cm, with locally higher amounts possible in some areas. Locations: parts of central and northeastern Newfoundland. Time span: Friday into Friday night. Remarks: A mixture of rain and snow will begin towards midnight tonight, and then transition to snow from west to east during the day Friday as temperatures fall. The snow will be heavy at times, and is expected to continue until tapering off around midnight on Friday. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall is possible over some areas. Locations: southwestern and western Newfoundland, Time span: early Friday morning until late Friday afternoon. Remarks: A mixture of rain and snow will begin this evening and then change to snow overnight into Friday morning. At this time only 5 to 10 cm of snow is expected, but there is some uncertainty with the forecast, with potential for higher amounts to shift into these regions. Should the weather system responsible for the snow shift westward, as much as 10 to 15 cm could fall in some areas. Please continue to monitor future forecasts in case snowfall warnings are required. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-19T10:28:28-00:00

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall, combined with melting snow, is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Locations: Connaigre. Total rainfall: 40 to 60 mm along the coast with lesser amounts inland. Time span: tonight through Friday morning. Remarks: A mixture of snow and rain will develop this evening then change to rain, at times heavy near midnight. The rain will change back to snow early Friday afternoon. The rain will be accompanied by mild temperatures resulting in significant snowmelt and runoff. Local flooding is possible, especially in areas with poor drainage. ### Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-19T10:26:52-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: southerly 100 km/h. Locations: southern Avalon Peninsula. Time span: early Friday evening. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Exposure is particularly a concern for individuals with chronic conditions such as asthma, COPD, heart disease, and diabetes, respiratory infections such as COVID-19, pregnant women, infants, and older adults. properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 60 to 80 km/h. Locations: along the Labrador coast from Rigolet to Hopedale. Time span: overnight tonight until Friday morning. Remarks: Fresh snowfall will combine with strengthening northwesterly winds tonight to produce poor visibility in blowing snow. Conditions will improve around noon on Friday. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-19T10:49:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-18T18:50:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0181136999.2021
Area: Rigolet and vicinity, Postville - Makkovik, Hopedale and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

ROAD DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR VERNON (March 18, 2021 - Vernon) The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Interior Health has continued a Road Dust Advisory issued on March 16, 2021 for Vernon due to high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation, dust suppression or a change in traffic patterns. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Exposure is a concern for pregnant women, infants, and older adults, as well as, individuals with conditions such as asthma, COPD, heart disease, diabetes or respiratory infections such as COVID-19. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions or acute infections should postpone or reduce strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Where appropriate, maintain physical distancing. Anyone experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, should follow the advice of their health care provider. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air.
